title: 114_hr3284
content: The Act titled "Mary Jo Lawyer Spano Mesothelioma Patient Registry Act of 2015" establishes a patient registry for mesothelioma data collection and research under Title III of the Public Health Service Act. The Secretary will develop a patient registry to collect data on mesothelioma in the United States, including information on incidence, prevalence, treatment outcomes, and patient longevity. The Secretary will establish a patient registry to gather data on mesothelioma in the United States, including incidence, prevalence, and demographic factors associated with the disease. The registry aims to support research, examine environmental and occupational factors, and make non-identifiable information accessible for research and prevention efforts. The patient registry will collect data on mesothelioma in the United States, including demographics, risk factors, diagnosis markers, and relevant analysis information. The Secretary will consult with experts on mesothelioma epidemiology, natural history, prevention, detection, management, treatment, and outcomes measures. This includes epidemiologists and representatives from national associations with experience in research and patient services for mesothelioma. The Secretary will consult with experts on mesothelioma epidemiology, prevention, detection, treatment, and outcomes measures. This includes epidemiologists, national associations with research and patient services for mesothelioma, health information technology experts, clinicians, and research scientists with translational research experience. The Secretary will coordinate with other federal agencies to share registry information and analysis. Public access to the information is subject to certain conditions. The Secretary will make information from the mesothelioma patient registry available to the public and researchers. Privacy protections will be as stringent as HIPAA laws. A report outlining findings in the registry must be submitted to Congress within 18 months of the Act's enactment. The Secretary will submit a report to Congress within 4 years of the Act's enactment on the development and maintenance of the mesothelioma patient registry, including future expansion plans and partnerships with research and patient advocacy communities. The mesothelioma patient registry will collect and store information, provide guidelines for use, and coordinate with other databases.
